Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: The role seed dispersal in forest ecosystem function: lessons from the oaks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of this project is to write a book that summarizes more than 25 years of research about how acorns are dispersed and why dispersal is important for regeneration of forests in eastern North America and many other places. Curiously, the same animals that disperse acorns (mostly rodents and jays) also destroy them by eating them. The book will demonstrate how these animals hide and often forget about acorns, allowing the acorns to germinate, oak seedlings to take root, and forests to grow. The book will show: (1) how differences among acorns influence where and when animals disperse them, (2) how acorn dispersal benefits forests, (3) how year-to-year differences in the size of acorn crops influence the dispersal process, (4) how acorn dispersal varies with forest type, and (5) how the activity of top predators in a forest ecosystem can fundamentally alter the process of acorn dispersal. This project will re-evaluate some of the traditional views of seed dispersal and will demonstrate that help of researchers from a variety of scientific disciplines is necessary for understanding how acorns are dispersed and why dispersal is important for conservation of oak forests.

The book will reveal new insights into how the underlying relationship between seeds and seed consumers (seed predators and dispersers) drive numerous ecological processes in forest ecosystems (e.g., forest structure, masting, the evolution of seed characteristics, and even predator/prey interactions), and how many of these processes feed back into the dispersal process. As such, this project will re-frame and re-evaluate some of the traditional views of seed dispersal and its influence on forest ecosystem processes. The book will support and promote improvements in oak forest management and conservation, especially in the context of climate change. The book will also have important implications for understanding the lack of oak regeneration, which is a significant problem in many deciduous forests of the U.S. and beyond (Northwest Canada, Spain, Portugal, and Scotland). Furthermore, it will be useful in developing plans for reintroduction of the American chestnut tree into its native range, and the potential impact of an invasive Asian oak species, now widespread throughout eastern North America. From an educational perspective, the project will provide: (1) new insights for students and researchers on the importance of multidisciplinary approaches for understanding complex ecological processes, (2) an opportunity for three or more undergraduates interested in scientific journalism to assist in the research, produce figures, and edit the book, and (3) dissemination of the book to a network of Primarily Undergraduate Institutions involved in the NSF-funded Ecological Research Educational Network initiative, as well as to high schools in northeastern Pennsylvania.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcome of this project was a book that reviews the authors 29 years of research on the interactions between oaks and their seed consumers (rodents, birds, and insects) and their ultimate influence on acorn dispersal, a key stage in the oak lifecycle. This synthesis (now in contract and in review at by Johns Hopkins University Press) centers on several, interrelated lines of investigation by the author's lab, and is designed to re-frame and re-evaluate some of the traditional views of animal-mediated seed dispersal and its influence on forest ecosystem processes. These include: (1) how seed traits directly influence the dispersal process; (2) how these behavioral decisions in turn influence forest structure; (3) how different groups of seed predators (jays, rodents, and insects in the case of oaks) respond differently to masting, and how dispersal patterns may influence the evolution of masting in trees and; (4) how seed characteristics of many oak species follow from their dual role of tolerance and resistance to seed predators and their benefit for dispersal; (5) how the dispersal process is context-dependent and varies with abundance of different seed types or forest composition; and (6) how top predators can drive the seed dispersal process by directly influencing the placement and establishment of seeds. More broadly, the synthesis provides a conceptual framework for investigating underlying mechanisms of a complex suite of ecological and evolutionary interactions that drive the process of animal-mediated dispersal, a fundamental process underlying many aspects of forest ecosystem function.

This synthesis is a comprehensive analysis of the seed dispersal process in the oaks, a dominant genus of trees represented by greater than 500 species worldwide. The book reveals new insights into how the underlying relationship between seeds and seed consumers (seed predators and dispersers) drive numerous ecological processes in forest ecosystems, and how many of these processes feed back into the dispersal process. As such, the book re-evaluates some of the traditional views of seed dispersal and its influence on forest ecosystem processes. The book also demonstrates the multidisciplinary approaches necessary for understanding the dispersal process and its influence on forest ecosystem function, as well as the management and conservation of forests. A clear understanding of the oak-animal interactions that contribute to acorn dispersal, seedling establishment, and regeneration are essential for habitat conservation and oak forest management, especially given the lack of oak regeneration and related conservation issues in many oak forests worldwide (e.g., western Canada, Spain, Portugal, Costa Rica, and the eastern United States). For example, the synthesis provides important implications for the challenge of regeneration of ecologically and economically important oaks in eastern deciduous forest, the proposed restoration of American chestnut (Castanea dentata) and the potential impact of an invasive ornamental oak (sawtooth oak, Q. acutissima), now widespread throughout the eastern U.S.

In addition to the book, the principal investigator, also coauthored 14 peer reviewed publications that are extensively reviewed in this book. These publications deal with (1) several aspects of masting in oaks, (2) long term patterns of cache management by tree squirrels, (3) the effects of relative frequencies of nut types on caching decisions in squirrels, and (4) the effects of acorn characteristics of several oak species on tolerance and resistance to seed predators during the germination process. In addition, two revised web pages (for the PI and the Wilkes University Institute for the Environment), both highlighting the book and these other publications (including some data files), are forthcoming.

This project also accomplished several additional goals. First, the book offers a new perspective for students and researchers on how an understanding of the fundamentals of the dispersal process underlie numerous other ecosystem processes. The project also (1) offers a technical reference on oak ecology for use by scientists, managers, and graduate students that serves as guide to oak forest ecology as well as an introduction to conservation and management of such forests, (2) involved several undergraduates and a research assistant in various aspects of book preparation (figure development, literature searches, bibliography preparation and light editing of the book; (4) provided a number of outreach activities indirectly related to the book for middle school, high school and university students including a formal lab exercise supported by the NSF-funded EREN network. Finally, each of the opening chapters in the book was illustrated by an accomplished artist, Dr. Tad Theimer, also a professional scientist with expertise in the study of seed dispersal
